msg_text.content: THERE IS NOT ENOUGH STORAGE TO REPRESENT THE ARRAY VALUE.

explanation.content: The amount of memory that is required to represent an array value is larger than the maximum allowed for the system.

programmer_response.content: Examples of actions that you can take are:

children.content: Reduce the number of elements in the array or the size of some of the elements.
Correct the statement that is attempting to create the array value.

msg_text.content: AN ERROR OCCURRED IN A KEY-EXPRESSION EVALUATION IN index-name INFORMATION RETURNED: SQLCODE: sqlcode, SQLSTATE: sqlstate, MESSAGE TOKEN token-list AND RID X rid

explanation.content: During evaluation of an index key-expression for a data change statement, an SQL error condition was encountered:

children.content: index-name
The index involved when the error occurred.
sqlcode
The SQLCODE received by the key-expression evaluation.
sqlstate
The corresponding SQLSTATE for the SQLCODE received by the key-expression evaluation.
token-list
The list of tokens from the original SQL error. This list might be truncated.
rid
The RID of the row which fails the key-expression evaluation.

system_programmer_response.content: Use the index name and RID number to determine the failing row of the table. If the index definition is available, use the column values of the failing row to determine the failing key-expression.

programmer_response.content: Contact your database administrator to determine why the index specified in the message received the error.

msg_text.content: FORMAT STRING format-string IS NOT VALID FOR THE function-name FUNCTION

explanation.content: An invalid format string was specified for the function.

children.content: format-string
The invalid format string. The format might be invalid for one or more of the following reasons:
The format string contains unsupported format elements or separator characters.
The format string does not contain a format element, is the empty string, or is all blanks.
The length of the format string argument exceeds the maximum allowable length.
A format element is specified multiple times.
The format string contains too many format elements.

The format string contains multiple format elements that represent the same component. For example, the TIMESTAMP_FORMAT function must not specify both YYYY and YY, which are format elements to indicate the year, in the format string.
A parameter marker was specified for the first argument and the format string includes a time zone format element
function-name
The name of the function.

programmer_response.content: Change the format string argument for the function.

msg_text.content: string-expression CANNOT BE INTERPRETED USING FORMAT STRING format-string FOR THE TIMESTAMP_FORMAT FUNCTION.

explanation.content: The string expression that was specified for the TIMESTAMP_FORMAT function cannot be interpreted with the specified format string to produce a timestamp value.

children.content: function-name
The name of the function. The name used to invoke the function could also be TO_DATE or TO_TIMESTAMP.
string-expression
The string expression.

explanation.content: Possible reasons for this error include:

children.content: The string expression is too long or too short for the specified format string.
The string expression does not conform to the template specified in the format string. For example, 92007 is not a valid value for YYYY, which indicates the year.
A value in the string expression is not valid for the corresponding format element in the format string. For example, 45 is not a valid value for DD, which indicates the day of the month.

programmer_response.content: Change the format string argument for the function.

msg_text.content: THE PROCEDURE procedure-name HAS ENCOUNTERED AN UNSUPPORTED       VERSION, version, FOR PARAMETER number

explanation.content: The version, version, specified for the parameter in ordinal position number is not supported by the procedure procedure-name.

user_response.content: Call the procedure and specify a supported version number for the parameter. The highest supported version number for the parameter can be obtained by calling the procedure and specifying NULL for the value of this parameter.

msg_text.content: THE BINARY XML VALUE IS INCOMPLETE OR CONTAINS UNRECOGNIZED DATA AT LOCATION position WITH THE HEX DATA text

explanation.content: An error occurred when processing a binary XML value.

children.content: position
A byte offset into the binary XML value.
text

The first eight bytes of XML data in hexadecimal. If the unrecognized data is located within the last eight bytes of the binary XML data, only the data starting at the location position up to the end of the binary XML data is returned.

programmer_response.content: Modify the binary XML value so that it conforms to the binary XML format, or change the application to use the textual XML format for data transfer.

msg_text.content: THE STATEMENT WAS NOT EXECUTED BECAUSE AN EXPRESSION IS NOT A CONSTANT OR VARIABLE. THE INVALID EXPRESSION IS IN THE STATEMENT NEAR THE SYNTAX ELEMENT syntax-element

explanation.content: The expression in the statement near the syntax element syntax-element must result in a single value, and must consist of one of the following elements:

children.content: A constant
A special register
A parameter marker
A variable
A deterministic function with no external action
An expression whose operands are any of the above elements

explanation.content: The expression cannot include any of the following elements:

children.content: A column name
A non-deterministic function
A function with external action
An expression whose operands are any of the above

user_response.content: Change the statement to specify an expression that results in a single value, and contains only elements in the list of allowed elements. Issue the statement again.

msg_text.content: ROW OR COLUMN ACCESS CONTROL CANNOT BE ACTIVATED FOR TABLE table-name FOR REASON reason-code. object-type object-name IS NOT IN A VALID STATE FOR ACTIVATING ACCESS CONTROL FOR THIS TABLE

explanation.content: Row access control cannot be activated explicitly or implicitly, or column access control cannot be activated explicitly for the table.

children.content: table-name
The name of the table.
reason-code
The reason for the message or SQL code, indicated by one of the following values:
The object-name view is defined on the table and the view is defined with the WITH CHECK OPTION clause.
The object-name trigger is defined for the table and the trigger is not defined as secure.
A view is defined on the table, the object-name trigger is defined for that view, and the trigger is not defined as secure.
The table is directly or indirectly referenced in the definition of a materialized query table.
The table is a created temporary table.
The table has a row permission or a column mask that is not valid because a previous attempt to regenerate it was unsuccessful.
The table cannot be activated for the row access control because the table contains a security label column.
The table cannot be activated for the row access control or column access control, because the table is a system-period temporal table, history table, archive-enabled table, or archive table.
object-type
The type of object.
object-name
The name of the object.

programmer_response.content: Correct the error and reissue the statement to activate row or column access control for the table. For the invalid state, disable the row permission or column mask. Then, drop and re-create it with the modified definition.

msg_text.content: object-type1 object-name1 MUST BE DEFINED AS SECURE BECAUSE object-type2 object-name2 IS DEPENDENT ON IT.

explanation.content: An object that must be defined as secure is not defined as secure.

children.content: object-type1 and object-name1
The type and name of the object that must be defined as secure, but that is not.
object-type2 and object-name2
The type and name of the object that depends on the object that is identified by object-name1.

explanation.content: The object that is identified by object-name2 depends on object-name1 for row or column access control.

In most cases, object-type2 is a row permission or column mask. But if object-type2 is a sourced user-defined function, object-name2 must be referenced in a row permission or column mask and object-name1 must be the underlying source of the user-defined function.

programmer_response.content: Alter the object that is identified by object-name1 to make it secure.

msg_text.content: THE INSERT OR UPDATE IS NOT ALLOWED BECAUSE A RESULTING ROW DOES NOT SATISFY ROW PERMISSIONS.

explanation.content: Row access control is enforced for the object of the insert or update operation. Consequently, all attempts to insert or update rows in that table are checked to ensure that the resulting rows conform to the row permissions defined for that table.

system_action.content: The statement cannot be processed. No insert or update operations were performed, and the contents of the table remain unchanged.

programmer_response.content: Examine the definitions of the row permissions to determine why the requested insert or update operation was not successful. This error might be a data-dependent condition.

msg_text.content: PERMISSION OR MASK object-name CANNOT BE ALTERED AS SPECIFIED. REASON CODE reason-code.

explanation.content: The ALTER MASK or ALTER PERMISSION statement could not be processed.

children.content: object-name
The name of the object.
reason-code
The reason for the message or SQL code, indicated by one of the following values:
A default row permission cannot be altered.
ENABLE cannot be specified because the object is invalid after a previous attempt to regenerate it was unsuccessful.

programmer_response.content: Specify the name of a row permission that can be changed. For the invalid state, disable the row permission or column mask, then drop and re-create it with the modified definition.

msg_text.content: THE INPUT ARGUMENT OF FUNCTION function-name THAT IS DEFINED WITH THE NOT-SECURED OPTION MUST NOT REFERENCE COLUMN column-name FOR WHICH A COLUMN MASK IS ENABLED AND THE COLUMN ACCESS CONTROL IS ACTIVATED FOR THE TABLE

explanation.content: The input argument of a function references a column when it must not do so. When a column mask is enabled and column access control is activated for a table, the input argument of an insecure function must not reference the column.

children.content: function-name
The name of the function.
column-name
The name of the column.

programmer_response.content: Take either of the following actions, and reinvoke the function.

children.content: Update the function invocation so that it does not reference the column that is identified by column-name.
Disable or drop the column mask.

msg_text.content: PERMISSION OR MASK CANNOT BE CREATED FOR THE object-name OBJECT OF THE object-type TYPE. REASON CODE reason-code.

explanation.content: The CREATE PERMISSION or CREATE MASK statement cannot be processed.

children.content: object-name
The name of the object.
object-type
The type of object.
reason-code
The reason for the message or SQL code, indicated by one of the following values:
The definition references the table for which the row permission or the column mask is being defined.
The definition references a table function or a collection-derived table (UNNEST).
The definition references a user-defined function that is not secure.
The definition references one of the following functions:
A function that is defined as not deterministic
A function that is defined to have an external action
A function that is defined with the MODIFIES SQL DATA option
The definition references an OLAP specification.
The definition references an XMLEXISTS predicate.
The definition references a ROW CHANGE expression.
The definition references a sequence reference.
The definition references a created or declared temporary table.
The definition references a table that was implicitly created for an XML column.
The definition references  or  in a SELECT clause.
name.*
The definition references a column that is defined with a FIELDPROC.
The definition references a language element that requires multiple encoding scheme processing.
The definition references an ordinary SQL identifier that contains a dash (-).
The body of a row permission or column mask includes a period specification.
One of the following situations occurred:
An attempt was made to create a row permission or column mask on one of the following table types: You cannot create row permissions or column masks on these types of tables.
A table that is defined with a period
A history table
An archive-enabled table
An archive table
An accelerator-only table
An attempt was made to implicitly create a default row permission for an ACTIVATE ROW ACCESS CONTROL specification.
The definition references a Db2 11 Unicode column in an EBCDIC table.
A column mask cannot be defined for a Db2 11 Unicode column in an EBCDIC table.
The column for which the mask is defined was done so with a field procedure (FIELDPROC).
The data type of the return expression is not the same as the data type of the column on which the column mask is defined.
The length attribute of the return expression is not the same as the length attribute of the column on which the column mask is defined.
The null attribute of the return expression is not the same as the null attribute of the column on which the column mask is defined.
The subtype, encoding scheme, or CCSID of the return expression is not the same as the corresponding attribute of the column on which the column mask is defined.

An attribute of the return expression is not the same as the corresponding attribute of the column on which the column mask is defined. The attribute is not one of the attributes that are described in reason codes 33-36.
The definition references an accelerator-only table.
A row permission cannot be created for a table that has a security label column.
A row permission cannot reference a table that has a security label column.
GROUPING SETS or super-groups cannot be specified in the definition of a column mask or a row permission control.

programmer_response.content: Correct the syntax, and reissue the statement.

msg_text.content: A COLUMN MASK IS ALREADY DEFINED FOR THE COLUMN column-name IN TABLE table-name (EXISTING MASK NAME mask-name)

explanation.content: An attempt was made to define a mask on a column, but a mask already exists on the column. Only one mask can be defined for a column.

children.content: column-name
The name of the column.
table-name
The name of the table.
mask-name
The name of the column mask that already exists.

programmer_response.content: To create the new mask, drop the existing mask, then reissue the statement.

msg_text.content: THE function-name FUNCTION WAS INVOKED WITH AN INVALID FORMAT STRING format-string.

explanation.content: An invalid format string was specified for the function-name function.

children.content: function-name
The name of the function. The value is either VARCHAR_FORMAT or DECFLOAT_FORMAT, even if the name used to invoke the function was TO_CHAR or TO_NUMBER.
format-string
The invalid format string.

explanation.content: A valid format string for the VARCHAR_FORMAT function must:

children.content: Have a data type length not greater than 254 bytes
Contain only supported format elements.
Not result in a string with an actual length that is greater than the length attribute of the result

explanation.content: A valid format string for the DECFLOAT_FORMAT function must:

children.content: Have a data type length not greater than 254 bytes
Contain at least one format element
Contain only supported format elements.

user_response.content: Change the format string argument of the function-name function.

msg_text.content: THE function-name FUNCTION IS NOT ABLE TO USE FORMAT STRING format-string TO INTERPRET THE ARGUMENT string-expression.

explanation.content: The function-name function was invoked with format-string and string-expression. This function-name value is DECFLOAT_FORMAT, even if the name used to invoke the function is TO_NUMBER. The value of the argument string-expression cannot be interpreted with the format string format-string to produce a DECFLOAT(34) value. This error can occur for any of the following reasons:

children.content: string-expression is too long for the specified format string

string-expression does not conform to the template specified in the format string; for example: Too many digits were specified in string-expression for the corresponding format element in the format string, such as in the specific case where 1234 is not a valid value for 999
A value in string-expression is not valid for the corresponding format element in the format string, such as in the specific case where $ is not a valid value for S

user_response.content: Change the arguments of the
function-name
function to valid values.

msg_text.content: THE STATEMENT CANNOT BE PROCESSED BECAUSE COLUMN MASK mask-name (DEFINED FOR COLUMN column-name) EXISTS AND THE COLUMN MASK CANNOT BE APPLIED OR THE DEFINITION OF THE MASK CONFLICTS WITH THE REQUESTED STATEMENT. REASON CODE reason-code.

explanation.content: The statement could not be processed because of a conflict with a column mask that is defined on a column.

children.content: mask-name
The name of the column mask.
column-name
The name of the column.
reason-code
The reason for the message or SQL code, indicated by one of the following values:
The result table of the select is derived from a set operation that involves one of the following set operators:
EXCEPT ALL
EXCEPT DISTINCT
INTERSECT ALL
INTERSECT DISTINCT
The column is referenced in the select list of the scalar fullselect and the result of the scalar fullselect expression is derived from one of the following set operators:
EXCEPT ALL
EXCEPT DISTINCT
INTERSECT ALL
INTERSECT DISTINCT
The result table is derived from a recursive common table expression and the column is specified in the fullselect of the recursive common table expression.
A column in the select list is an INCLUDE column for a data change statement that is derived from the column for which the mask is defined. The column mask cannot be applied in this context.
The result table is derived from a table function and the column was specified as an input argument to the table function.
A column in the select list is derived from an OLAP specification and the column is referenced in the partitioning expression or sort key expression of the OLAP specification.
The column is referenced in a WHEN clause of a CASE expression.
The column is referenced in an aggregate function with keyword DISTINCT.
A sort key expression for ARRAY_AGG, LISTAGG, PERCENTILE_CONT, PERCENTILE_DISC or MEDIAN references a column for which a column mask is defined.

An insert or update operation uses a masked value that is returned from the mask and column that are identified in the message, and the expression that is specified in the THEN or ELSE clause of the column mask definition is not a simple reference to the column.When the object table is column access control activated, for an insert or update operation, the return expression in the column mask definition must be a simple reference to the column for which the mask is defined.
The query includes a GROUPING SETS, CUBE or ROLLUP clause.

programmer_response.content: Check the application compatibility value that is used by your application to ensure that it is set properly. The behavior of the statement might change based on the application compatibility level.
Take the action that corresponds to the reason-code value, and reissue the statement.

children.content: Either do not reference the column in the select list or do not use the set operation in this context.
Either do not reference the column in the select list of the scalar-fullselect expression or do not use a set operator to derive the result of the scalar-fullselect expression in this context.
Either remove the reference to the column of the recursive common table expression from the select list or do not use the recursive common table expression in this context.
Either remove the INCLUDE column from the select list or do not derive the INCLUDE column from the column name.
Either do not reference the table function or do not specify the column as input to the table function.
Either do not reference the column in the OLAP expression or do not use the OLAP expression in this context.
Either change the query to remove the reference to the column in the CASE expression or do not reference the CASE expression in this context.
Either remove the reference to the column from the definition of the aggregate function or do not specify the DISTINCT clause in this context.

Either change the statement to remove the reference to the column in the insert or update operation, or contact the security administrator to ask them to deactivate the column access control from the object table or modify the return expression in the column mask definition.
Remove the GROUPING SETS, CUBE or ROLLUP clause from the query.

msg_text.content: THE SOURCE TABLE table-name CANNOT BE ALTERED AS SPECIFIED BECAUSE THE TABLE IS INVOLVED IN ROW OR COLUMN ACCESS CONTROLS. REASON CODE reason-code.

explanation.content: An unsuccessful attempt was made to alter or rename a table that is involved in row or column access controls.

children.content: table-name
The name of the table.
reason-code
The reason for the message or SQL code, indicated by one of the following values:
The table is referenced in one or more column mask or row permission definitions.
A column in the table is referenced in one or more column mask or row permission definitions.

user_response.content: Correct the syntax, and reissue the statement.

msg_text.content: HASH ORGANIZATION CLAUSE IS NOT VALID FOR table-name

explanation.content: The table cannot be altered as specified.

children.content: table-name
The name of the table.

explanation.content: Possible causes for this error include:

children.content: A clause was specified on an ALTER TABLE statement, but the attribute cannot be set or changed because the table is not defined with hash organization.
ADD ORGANIZE BY HASH was specified on an ALTER TABLE statement, but the table is already defined with hash organization.
ADD ORGANIZE BY HASH was specified on an ALTER TABLE statement, but the table is already defined with a clustering index. Hash organization cannot be added to a table with a clustering index.
ADD ORGANIZE BY HASH was specified on an ALTER TABLE statement, but either the table is defined with APPEND YES, or it is a materialized query table.

ADD ORGANIZE BY HASH was specified on an ALTER TABLE statement, but the table is defined in a table space that is defined with MEMBER CLUSTER. Or, hash organization was specified on a CREATE TABLE statement that specifies a table space which is defined with MEMBER CLUSTER.
HASH SPACE was specified on a table that is not defined to be organized by hash. If the table is not defined with hash organization, the HASH SPACE keyword is invalid in a partition element.
HASH SPACE was specified on a table that resides in a table space which is not in reordered row format.

user_response.content: Either correct the syntax of the statement or specify a different table. Then reissue the statement.

msg_text.content: SPECIFIED HASH SPACE IS TOO LARGE FOR THE IMPLICITLY CREATED TABLE SPACE. REASON reason-code. (PARTITION partition-number)

explanation.content: Db2 attempted to implicitly create a table space, but the specified hash space is too large for the associated table space.

children.content: reason-code
A numeric value that indicates the type of table space:
A partition-by-range table space.
A partition-by-growth table space.
partition-number

For a partition-by-range table space, partition-number value indicates the partition for which the HASH SPACE value is too large. For partition-by-growth table spaces, the partition number is not relevant, and is indicated as .
*N

user_response.content: Take either of the following actions:

children.content: Explicitly create a table space with a larger DSSIZE specification, and specify that table space in the CREATE TABLE statement.
Reduce the HASH SPACE specification.

msg_text.content: A VERSIONING CLAUSE WAS SPECIFIED FOR TABLE table-name, BUT THE TABLE CANNOT BE USED AS A SYSTEM PERIOD TEMPORAL TABLE. REASON CODE = reason-code.

explanation.content: The ALTER TABLE statement attempted to make the table into a system-period temporal table, but the table definition is not valid.

children.content: table-name
The name of the table.
reason-code
The reason for the message or SQL code, indicated by one of the following values:
The table is already defined as a system-period temporal table or history table.
The table does not have a SYSTEM_TIME period or a transaction start ID column. A system-period temporal table must have both a SYSTEM_TIME period and a transaction start ID column.
The table is a materialized query table.
The transaction-start-ID column must be defined with the same data type, length, precision, and scale as the row-begin column and row-end column of the SYSTEM_TIME period in the table.
The table is an archive-enabled table or an archive table.

user_response.content: Correct the syntax, and resubmit the statement.

msg_text.content: INVALID SPECIFICATION OF PERIOD period-name. REASON CODE = reason-code.

explanation.content: The specification of an attribute in a CREATE or ALTER statement for a period is invalid.

children.content: period-name
The period that contains the invalid specification.
reason-code
A numeric value that indicates why the attribute might be invalid:
The start column name must not be the same as the end column name for the period.
The name of a column in a period must not be the same as a column used in the definition of another period for the table.
The data type, length, precision, and scale for the start column must be the same as for the end column.
For a BUSINESS_TIME period, the column must not be a column defined with a GENERATED clause.
For a SYSTEM_TIME period, the attributes of the start column and end column must be one of the combinations:
The start column definition is GENERATED ALWAYS AS ROW BEGIN and the end column definition is GENERATED ALWAYS AS ROW END.
The start column definition is GENERATED BY DEFAULT AS ROW BEGIN and the end column definition is GENERATED BY DEFAULT AS ROW END.

user_response.content: Correct the syntax, and resubmit the statement.

msg_text.content: A TIMESTAMP WITHOUT TIME ZONE VALUE CANNOT BE ASSIGNED TO A TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE TARGET

explanation.content: The statement attempted to assign a timestamp without time zone value to a target that is defined as timestamp with time zone. This error can occur on a FETCH, SELECT INTO, or CALL statement.

user_response.content: Change the application to first cast the timestamp without a time zone value to a timestamp with a time zone value before making the assignment to the target.

msg_text.content: A PUBLIC ALIAS NAME, name, CAN ONLY BE QUALIFIED WITH SYSPUBLIC AND NOT THE SCHEMA NAME schema-name.

explanation.content: A qualified name was specified for a public alias but the qualifier was not SYSPUBLIC.

user_response.content: Change the two-part name to a one-part name or specify the qualifier SYSPUBLIC. If a public alias was not intended and PUBLIC was specified in the statement, remove the keyword PUBLIC.

msg_text.content: A STRING REPRESENTATION OF A DATETIME VALUE THAT CONTAINS A TIME ZONE CANNOT BE IMPLICITLY OR EXPLICITLY CAST TO A TARGET DEFINED AS DATETIME WITHOUT TIME ZONE

explanation.content: The statement attempted to cast a string representation of a datetime value that contains a time zone to a datetime target that is defined to not have a time zone. This action is not supported.

user_response.content: Change the application to first cast the string value with a time zone to a datetime value with a time zone, and then cast the result to a datetime value without a time zone. Then make the assignment to the target.

msg_text.content: THE WITH ORDINALITY CLAUSE IS NOT VALID WITH UNNEST OF AN ASSOCIATIVE ARRAY.

explanation.content: A collection-derived table reference contained the WITH ORDINALITY clause and an UNNEST invocation in which the argument was an associative array. An associative array and the WITH ORDINALITY clause are not compatible because an associative array is not organized according to ordinal position.

programmer_response.content: Remove the WITH ORDINALITY clause, or change the argument of UNNEST to an ordinary array.

msg_text.content: XMLMODIFY ATTEMPTED TO UPDATE A COLUMN WHICH WAS NOT SPECIFIED IN THE UPDATE SET CLAUSE

explanation.content: The XQuery updating expression in the XMLMODIFY function invocation attempted to update XML nodes that are not part of the column that is the target of the SET assignment clause that contains the XMLMODIFY function invocation. The XMLMODIFY function can update XML nodes in the target column only.

programmer_response.content: Change the XQuery updating expression in the XMLMODIFY function to only refer to XML nodes that are part of the column that is a target of the assignment.

msg_text.content: INVALID SPECIFICATION OF WITHOUT OVERLAPS OR PERIOD CLAUSE. REASON CODE reason-code.

explanation.content: The specification of the WITHOUT OVERLAPS clause was invalid.

children.content: reason-code
The reason why the specification was invalid:
The columns of the specified period must not be specified in the constraint clause.
WITHOUT OVERLAPS can be specified in a CREATE INDEX statement only if the index is defined as UNIQUE. It cannot be specified if the index is defined as UNIQUE WHERE NOT NULL.
The columns of the specified period must not be specified in the index specification.
WITHOUT OVERLAPS cannot be specified for an index that is defined with PARTITION BY RANGE.
A key expression that is not a simple column reference must not be specified for the key or index when WITHOUT OVERLAPS is also specified.
WITH OVERLAPS can be specified in a CREATE INDEX statement only if the index is not defined as UNIQUE or UNIQUE WHERE NOT NULL.
WITHOUT OVERLAPS cannot be specified for an index, if the table is defined with a partitioning key that includes any columns of the BUSINESS_TIME period.

user_response.content: Correct the syntax, and resubmit the statement.

msg_text.content: TABLE table-name WAS SPECIFIED AS A HISTORY TABLE, BUT THE TABLE DEFINITION IS NOT VALID FOR A HISTORY TABLE. REASON CODE = reason-code.

explanation.content: A table is specified as a history table in a CREATE TABLE statement or an ALTER TABLE statement, but the table definition is invalid.

children.content: table-name
The name of the table.
reason-code
A numeric value that indicates the requirement that might make the definition invalid:
The table must not be any of the following tables:
System-period temporal table. The table was defined as a system-period temporal table by a previous statement, or the current statement defines the table as a system-period temporal table.
History table.
Declared global temporary table.
Created global temporary table.
Materialized query table.
View.
Auxiliary table.
Clone table.
Table that has a clone.
Table that was implicitly created for an XML column.
An archive-enabled table or archive table.
The table definition must be complete.
The table must be the only table in the table space.
The table must not contain any of the following columns:
Identity column
Row change timestamp column
Row begin column
Row end column
Transaction start ID column
Generated expression column
The table must not include a period definition.
The table must not be involved in any referential integrity constraints.
The history table must have the same number and order of columns as the table that is to be used as a system-period temporal table.
The table must not contain a security label column.
If a column in the system-period temporal table is defined as ROWID, the corresponding history column must be defined as ROWID with the GENERATED ALWAYS attribute.
The corresponding columns of the system-period temporal table and associated history table must have the same value for the following attributes:
Column name
Data type
Data type length (excluding inline LOB length or XML length in the base table), precision, and scale
Null attribute
Hidden attribute
Field procedure
FOR MIXED, BIT, or SBCS DATA attribute and CCSID
The table must not have a column mask or row permission.

user_response.content: Correct the syntax, and resubmit the statement.

msg_text.content: INVALID PERIOD SPECIFICATION OR PERIOD CLAUSE FOR PERIOD period-name. REASON CODE = reason-code.

explanation.content: A period specification or period clause is invalid.

children.content: period-name
The period that is invalid.
reason-code
A numeric value that indicates why the period is invalid:
The period name was specified more than one time for the table reference.
The SYSTEM_TIME period was specified, but the table is not a system-period temporal table.

period-name violated the following requirement: each expression must return a value of a built-in data type and can contain any of the following supported operands:These rules have the following exceptions:
A constant
A special register
A variable, which can be either a host variable, an SQL variable, an SQL parameter, a transition variable, or a global variable
A parameter marker
A CAST specification, where the cast operand is a supported operand
An expression that uses arithmetic operators and operands
A scalar function whose arguments are supported operands (Nested function invocations are not permitted.)
A period specification or period clause for a view must not contain an untyped parameter marker.
The source expression of SET CURRENT TEMPORAL BUSINESS_TIME and SET CURRENT TEMPORAL SYSTEM_TIME statements must not contain a parameter marker or a transition variable.
The period specification or period clause was specified for a view where the view definition includes a user-defined function.

The precision of an expression must be greater than the precision of the columns of the period. If the expression is a string, it is first converted to a timestamp, and the value must not contain more significant fractional seconds digits than the precision of the column.

FOR SYSTEM_TIME was specified. However, the value of the CURRENT TEMPORAL SYSTEM_TIME special register is not null, and the SYSTIMESENSITIVE bind option is set to YES. Therefore, you cannot also explicitly specify FOR SYSTEM_TIME.

FOR BUSINESS_TIME was specified. However, the value of the CURRENT TEMPORAL BUSINESS_TIME special register is not null, and the BUSTIMESENSITIVE bind option is set to YES. Therefore, you cannot also explicitly specify FOR BUSINESS_TIME.
The period specification or period clause was specified for one of the following items:
A table that is not an application-period temporal table
A view for which an application-period temporal table is not referenced in the outermost FROM clause of the view definition, or an INSTEAD OF trigger is defined on the view.
An expression must not return a value with a time zone if the begin and end columns of the specified period are defined as timestamp without time zone.

user_response.content: Correct the syntax and resubmit the statement.

msg_text.content: THE REQUESTED ACTION IS NOT VALID FOR TABLE table-name BECAUSE THE TABLE IS THE WRONG TYPE OF TABLE. REASON CODE = reason-code

explanation.content: The table cannot be used as specified.

children.content: table-name
The name of the table.
reason-code
The reason for the message or SQL code, indicated by one of the following values:
An ALTER TABLE statement with an ADD PERIOD clause was specified for a history table, an archive-enabled table, or an archive table. A period cannot be specified for these types of tables.
An ALTER TABLE statement with a DROP VERSIONING clause was specified, but the table is not a system-period temporal table.

An ALTER TABLE statement with a DROP VERSIONING clause was specified. However, system-period data versioning cannot be dropped if there are any triggers, functions, procedures, views, or materialized query tables that reference historical versions of rows in the table.
An ALTER TABLE statement with a ROTATE PARTITION clause was specified for a system-period temporal table, a history table, an archive-enabled table, or an archive table.
An ALTER TABLE statement with an ADD CLONE clause was specified for a system-period temporal table, a history table, an archive-enabled table, or an archive table.
A TRUNCATE statement attempted to truncate a system-period temporal table. A system-period temporal table cannot be truncated.
An ALTER TABLESPACE statement attempted to alter the CCSID of a table space that contains a system-period temporal table, a history table, an archive-enabled table, or an archive table.
A CREATE TABLE or ALTER TABLE statement attempted to define a referential constraint where either the parent or child table is a history table or an archive table.
An ALTER TABLE statement with an ADD COLUMN clause was specified for a history table or an archive table.
An ALTER TABLE statement was specified to add a generated column other than a ROWID to a system-period temporal table or archive-enabled table.
An ALTER TABLE statement with a DISABLE ARCHIVE clause was specified, but the table is not an archive-enabled table.

user_response.content: Change the statement to specify the name of a table for which the action is valid, or specify a different action for the current table.

msg_text.content: period-name IS NOT A PERIOD IN TABLE table-name

explanation.content: The specified period does not exist in the specified table.

children.content: period-name
The name of the period.
table-name
The name of the table.

user_response.content: Verify that the SQL statement contains the correct period and table names, including any required qualifiers.

msg_text.content: THE TARGET OF THE DATA CHANGE OPERATION IS A TABLE table-name, WHICH INCLUDES A PERIOD period-name. A ROW THAT THIS DATA CHANGE OPERATION ATTEMPTED TO MODIFY WAS ALSO MODIFIED BY ANOTHER TRANSACTION.

explanation.content: An attempt was made to change a row in a system-period temporal table, but the row has been modified by another transaction. The requested change would result in a row in the associated history table whose row-begin column is higher than the row-end column.

children.content: table-name
The name of the system-period temporal table.
period-name
The name of the period.

explanation.content: This error can occur when two concurrent transactions are accessing the same row for data changes.

user_response.content: Reissue the statement.

msg_text.content: THE ARGUMENT OF THE WRAP FUNCTION OR CREATE_WRAPPED PROCEDURE IS NOT VALID

explanation.content: The argument of the WRAP function or the CREATE_WRAPPED procedure is not a valid SQL statement. The valid statements are:

children.content: CREATE FUNCTION (compiled SQL scalar)
CREATE FUNCTION (inlined SQL scalar)
CREATE FUNCTION (SQL table)
CREATE PROCEDURE (SQL - native)
CREATE TRIGGER (basic)
CREATE TRIGGER (advanced)

system_action.content: The statement that contains the WRAP function or CREATE_WRAPPED procedure cannot be processed.

programmer_response.content: Make sure the argument to the WRAP function or the CREATE_WRAPPED procedure is a valid statement.

msg_text.content: AN OBFUSCATED STATEMENT IS NOT VALID. REASON CODE= reason-code.

explanation.content: An error occurred during processing of a data definition statement that includes the WRAPPED clause.

children.content: reason-code
The Db2 reason code value that indicates the reason for the failure. For explanations of reason codes, see Db2 reason codes.

explanation.content: reason-code is one of the following values:

children.content: The statement was wrapped on a platform or version that is not supported.
The obfuscated portion of the statement is corrupted.

programmer_response.content: Ensure that the statement was wrapped on a supported platform, and that the statement is not corrupted.

msg_text.content: THE VERSION NUMBER actual-version SPECIFIED IN A BINARY XML VALUE IS NOT SUPPORTED. THE HIGHEST SUPPORTED VERSION IS supported-version.

explanation.content: The version number contained in a binary XML value specifies a version of the binary XML specification that is not supported. The binary XML value cannot be parsed.

children.content: actual-version
The version that is specified.
supported-version
The highest version of the binary XML specification that is known to be supported.

programmer_response.content: Make sure that XML values either are formatted as binary XML data conforming to a version of the binary XML specification that the server supports or are formatted as textual XML data.

msg_text.content: THE DATA CHANGE OPERATION operation IS NOT SUPPORTED FOR THE TARGET OBJECT object-name BECAUSE OF AN IMPLICIT OR EXPLICIT SYSTEM PERIOD SPECIFICATION INVOLVING period-name. REASON CODE: reason-code.

explanation.content: Db2 cannot perform the specified data change operation, because the target of the operation references a temporal table for which a period specification is in effect. The period specification was either implicitly specified by a special register or explicitly specified in the fullselect that was specified as the target.

children.content: operation
The data change operation.
object-name
The name of the target object.
period-name
The name of the period that is invalid. Possible values are BUSINESS_TIME or SYSTEM_TIME.
reason-code
A numeric value that indicates why the operation is invalid. reason-code can have one of the following values:
The data in a system-period temporal table cannot be changed when a period specification is in effect. In this case, this restriction was violated, because both of the following conditions exist:
The data change operation directly or indirectly references a system-period temporal table. The target of the operation is one of the following objects:
A system period temporal table
A view that is defined with an outer fullselect that either directly or indirectly references a system-period temporal table in the FROM clause
A period specification is in effect, because the CURRENT TEMPORAL SYSTEM_TIME special register contains a non-null value, and the SYSTIMESENSITIVE bind option is set to YES.

user_response.content: Take the action for the specified reason code:

children.content: Take one of the following actions:
Set the CURRENT TEMPORAL SYSTEM_TIME special register to the null value and try the data change operation again.
If the statement is in a package that you do not want to be affected by the setting of the CURRENT TEMPORAL SYSTEM_TIME special register, bind the package with SYSTIMESENSITIVE NO.

msg_text.content: THE QUERY FAILED BECAUSE A NEGATIVE VALUE OR THE NULL VALUE IS USED IN THE clause CLAUSE

explanation.content: A query can include an OFFSET clause to begin fetching rows starting at a specified row number. A query can include a FETCH FIRST clause or a LIMIT clause, with or without an associated OFFSET clause, to control the number of rows that are returned from the query. The row count value for these clauses can be specified as a constant or variable that must be a positive numeric value or zero. The value must not be the null value.

children.content: clause
The clause that contains the negative value or the NULL value.

user_response.content: Change the clause to specify a positive number or zero, and issue the query again.

msg_text.content: THE STATEMENT FAILED BECAUSE THE TARGET OF AN ASSIGNMENT IS A READ-ONLY VARIABLE. VARIABLE NAME: variable-name.

explanation.content: Global variables can generally be used as the target of an assignment in various SQL statements, with the appropriate write access. However, the definition of some global variables makes them read-only. This applies to some built-in global variables and also to user-defined variables that are defined using the CONSTANT clause. A variable that is read-only cannot be used in an SQL statement as the target of an assignment.

children.content: variable-name
The name of the variable that is read-only.

programmer_response.content: Change the target variable to a variable that is not read-only.

msg_text.content: AN ARGUMENT, OR COMBINATION OF ARGUMENTS, SPECIFIED FOR THE operator-name OPERATOR ARE NOT VALID.

explanation.content: An operator was specified with an argument, or combination of arguments, that are not valid in the context where they were used.

children.content: operator-name
The name of the operator with the invalid arguments.

explanation.content: If the operator name is UNNEST, the error was issued for one of the following reasons:

children.content: More than one associative array argument was specified.
One ordinary array argument was specified with an associative array argument.
An argument must not include a scalar fullselect.

programmer_response.content: Change the array arguments or the operator.
If the operator name is UNNEST, take one of the following actions:

children.content: Specify only one associative array argument.
Specify ordinary array arguments only with other ordinary array arguments.
Specify an expression that does not include a scalar fullselect.

msg_text.content: CONSTRUCTING AN ASSOCIATIVE ARRAY FAILED BECAUSE THE INPUT DATA INCLUDES AT LEAST ONE DUPLICATE ARRAY INDEX VALUE. DUPLICATED INDEX VALUE: value.

explanation.content: In an associative array, each element is associated with a unique index value. When the ARRAY_AGG aggregate function is used to construct an array, if more than one element is associated with the same array index value, only one of the element values can be included in the array. This potential loss of element data is the reason that index values must be unique within the input data that is used to construct an associative array.

children.content: value
The duplicate array index value.

user_response.content: Change the input data so that there are no duplicate array index values. When you use the ARRAY_AGG aggregate function, you might need to add predicates to the query that produces the aggregation grouping sets to ensure that none of the rows include duplicate values for the index-expression argument of the ARRAY_AGG function.

msg_text.content: AN ENABLE ARCHIVE CLAUSE WAS SPECIFIED FOR TABLE table-name, BUT THE TABLE CANNOT BE USED AS AN ARCHIVE-ENABLED TABLE. REASON CODE = reason-code.

explanation.content: The ALTER TABLE statement attempted to define a table as an archive-enabled table, but the table definition is not valid.

children.content: table-name
The name of the table.
reason-code
A numeric value that identifies the reason for the error. reason-code can have one of the following values:
The table is already defined as an archive-enabled table or an archive table.
The table is a materialized query table.
The table has a column mask or row permission.
The table is a system-period temporal table or history table.
The table includes a period definition.

user_response.content: Correct the syntax and resubmit the statement.

msg_text.content: TABLE table-name WAS SPECIFIED AS AN ARCHIVE TABLE, BUT THE TABLE DEFINITION IS NOT VALID FOR AN ARCHIVE TABLE. REASON CODE = reason-code.

explanation.content: An ALTER TABLE statement attempted to define a table as an archive table, but the table definition is not valid.

children.content: table-name
The name of the table that was specified to be an archive table.
reason-code
A numeric value that identifies the reason for the error. reason-code can have one of the following values:
The table is an existing archive table or one of the following types of tables:  None of these tables can be defined as an archive table.
Archive-enabled table. The table was defined as an archive-enabled table by a previous statement, or the current statement defines the table as an archive-enabled table.
System-period temporal table.
History table.
Declared global temporary table.
Created global temporary table.
Materialized query table.
View.
Auxiliary table.
Clone table.
Table with a clone defined on it.
Table that was implicitly created for an XML column.
The table has an incomplete table definition.
The table is not the only table in the table space. An archive table must be the only table in the table space.
The table contains an identity column, a row-begin column, a row-end column, a transaction-start-ID column, or a generated expression column. Archive tables cannot contain any of these columns.
The table includes a period definition, which is not allowed for an archive table.
The table is involved in a referential integrity constraint, which is not allowed for an archive table.
The archive table does not have the same number of columns as the table that is to be used as the archive-enabled table. Both of these tables must have the same number of columns.
The table contains a security label column, which is not allowed in an archive table.

The table does not have a ROWID column to correspond to the one in the table that is to be used as the archive-enabled table. If the archive-enabled table has a ROWID column, the corresponding archive table column must be a ROWID column with the GENERATED ALWAYS attribute.

One of the following column attributes does not match the attribute for the corresponding column in the table that is to be used as the archive-enabled table: These attributes for the corresponding columns of an archive-enabled table and the associated archive table must be the same.
Name
Data type
Data type length (excluding inline LOB length or XML length in the base table), precision, and scale
Null attribute
Hidden attribute
Field procedure
FOR BIT, SBCS, or MIXED DATA attribute
CCSID
The table has a column mask or row permission, neither of which are allowed for an archive table.

The table does not have a row change timestamp column to correspond to the one in the table that is to be used as the archive-enabled table. If the archive-enabled table has a row change timestamp column, the corresponding archive table column must be a row change timestamp column with the GENERATED ALWAYS attribute.

user_response.content: Correct the syntax and resubmit the statement.

msg_text.content: AN ARCHIVE-ENABLED TABLE IS NOT ALLOWED IN THE SPECIFIED CONTEXT. REASON CODE reason-code.

explanation.content: The statement or query cannot reference an archive-enabled table for the indicated reason.

children.content: reason-code
A numeric value that identifies the reason for the error. reason-code can have one of the following values:

The SQL statement cannot reference both an archive-enabled table and a temporal table. (The temporal table can be either a system-period temporal table or an application-period temporal table.) For example, a query, a view definition, or an INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE statement cannot reference both of these table types.
You cannot insert rows into or update an archive-enabled table when the value of the SYSIBMADM.MOVE_TO_ARCHIVE global variable is Y.
An SQL table function cannot reference an archive-enabled table when both of the following conditions are true:
The value of the SYSIBMADM.GET_ARCHIVE global variable is Y.
The value of the ARCHIVESENSITIVE bind option is YES.
The definition of a row permission or column mask that is activated by a data change statement or query cannot reference an archive-enabled table when both of the following conditions are true:
The value of the SYSIBMADM.GET_ARCHIVE global variable is Y.
The value of the ARCHIVESENSITIVE bind option is YES.
In the trigger definition, the search-condition in the WHEN clause cannot reference an archive-enabled table if the trigger package was bound with ARCHIVESENSITIVE(YES).

user_response.content: Change the query or statement to remove the reference to the archive-enabled table and specify another table.

msg_text.content: THE OPERATION FAILED BECAUSE MULTIPLE RESULT VALUES CANNOT BE RETURNED FROM A SCALAR FUNCTION function-name.

explanation.content: A scalar function was invoked with arguments that do not allow the return of multiple result values for a single invocation. The processing of the scalar function determined a result the consisted of multiple values.

children.content: function-name
Identifies the name of the function that returned the error.

user_response.content: One of the following options can be used to avoid the error:

children.content: Change the values of the input arguments to the scalar function to return a single value from the multiple value result.
As an alternative to the scalar function invocation, create a user-defined table function, if possible, to return a result with multiple values.

msg_text.content: THE REPLACEMENT VALUE FOR built-in-global-var IS INVALID

explanation.content: The value specified for assignment to a built-in global variable is not a valid for that built-in global variable.

programmer_response.content: Correct the replacement value.

msg_text.content: TABLE table-name CANNOT BE DEFINED AS A DEPENDENT OF REFERENTIAL CONSTRAINT constraint-name. REASON reason-codereason-code.

explanation.content: The object of an ALTER TABLE statement cannot be defined as a dependent table in a referential constraint for the reason indicated by the reason code.

children.content: table-name
The name of the table that is named as the dependent table.
constraint-name
The name of the referential constraint in which the altered table that is the dependent table.
reason-code
The reason for the message or SQL code, indicated by one of the following values:

PERIOD BUSINESS_TIME was specified as part of a temporal referential constraint definition that would result in a referential cycle. The parent and child tables must not be the same table in a temporal referential constraint, and the child table must not be a descendent, directly or indirectly, of another table that is a descendent of the parent table.
An index that enforces a temporal referential constraint contains an INCLUDE column. This is not allowed.

user_response.content: Correct the constraint definition.

msg_text.content: EXECUTION FAILED DUE TO A DISTRIBUTION PROTOCOL ERROR THAT WILL NOT AFFECT THE SUCCESSFUL EXECUTION OF SUBSEQUENT COMMANDS OR SQL STATEMENTS: REASON reason-code (sub-code)

explanation.content: A DRDA protocol error has resulted which prevented successful execution of the current SQL statement. The error was such that it will not preclude the successful execution of further SQL statements.

system_action.content: The statement cannot be processed. The SQLCA is formatted. Message DSNL031I or DSNL032I, which might contain additional diagnostic information, might be issued to the MVS console.

problem_determination.content: The 'reason-code' identifies the DDM code point which represents the DDM reply message received from the remote server in response to the attempt to execute the SQL statement. These represent internal errors detected at the remote server or possibly, by the local Db2 functions.
The 'reason-code' value is the two-byte hexadecimal code point for the DDM reply message that represents the error and is one of the following:

children.content: X'1254' - CMDCHKRM
X'220A' - DSCINVRM
X'220E' - DTAMCHRM
X'1245' - PRCCNVRM
X'2202' - QRYNOPRM
X'220F' - QRYPOPRM
X'2207' - RDBACCRM
X'2204' - RDBNACRM
X'124C' - SYNTAXRM

problem_determination.content: A two-byte 'sub-code' accompanies 'reason-codes' X'220A' (DSCINVRM), X'1245' (PRCCNVRM), and X'124C' (SYNTAXRM). In all other cases, the 'sub-code' is zero.

The 'sub-code' when nonzero, consists of two bytes such that the high-order byte indicates the site at which the error was detected. This is X'01' if the error was detected by the local Db2; it is X'02' if the error was detected by the remote server. The low-order byte is dependent on the 'reason-code' as follows:

children.content: Description Error Code (DSCERRCD) if 'reason-code' = X'220A' (DSCINVRM).
Syntax Error Code (SYNERRCD) if 'reason-code' = X'124C' SYNTAXRM).
Conversational Protocol Error Code (PRCCVNCD) if 'reason-code' = X'1245' (PRCCNVRM).

problem_determination.content: Refer to the Open Group Technical Standard, DRDA Version 3 Vol. 3: Distributed Data Management Architecture for a detailed discussion of the semantics of the DDM terms DSCERRCD, SYNERRCD, and PRCCNVCD.

programmer_response.content: Notify the DBA for assistance in analysis of the SQL statement which yielded this SQLCODE.

msg_text.content: THE SQL STATEMENT CANNOT BE EXECUTED DUE TO A PRIOR CONDITION IN A CHAIN OF STATEMENTS

explanation.content: An SQL statement was chained to PREPARE, but the PREPARE statement has received a warning SQLCODE that requires the program or user to either re-issue the chained statement or issue a different SQL request. This error can occur only in a client/server environment.

children.content: A distributed client using DRDA has chained an OPEN statement to a PREPARE, but the PREPARE statement received SQLCODE +495.

system_action.content: The statement cannot be executed as chained.

programmer_response.content: The statement must be sent again as a separate request.

msg_text.content: EXECUTION FAILED BECAUSE FUNCTION NOT SUPPORTED BY THE SERVER: LOCATION location-name PRODUCT ID product-identifier REASON reason-code (sub-code)

explanation.content: The current SQL statement failed because the SQL statement was routed to a server that does not support the requested function. The error was such that it will not preclude the successful processing of further SQL statements.

children.content: location-name
The name of the server that could not support the required database protocols to perform the requested function.
product-identifier
An alphanumeric string that identifies the product.

The format of product identifier values is pppvvrrm, where ppp is a 3-letter product code (such as DSN for Db2), vv is the version, rr is the release, and m is the modification level. For example, DSN12015 identifies Db2 12 after the activation of function level 500 or higher. The product code (ppp) is one of the following values: Modification (m) values have the following meanings:
for IBM Db2 Analytics Accelerator for z/OS
AQT
for DB2 Server for VSE & VM
ARI
for Db2 for z/OS
DSN
for IBM Data Server Driver for JDBC and SQLJ
JCC
for DB2 for i
QSQ
for Db2 for Linux, UNIX, and Windows
SQL
Function level 100 or 100*.
Function level 500 or higher.
reason-code
A numeric value that identifies the function. Possible values are:
LONG_STMTS
LONG255_IDS
EXTENDED_DESCRIBE
EXTENDED_DIAGNOSTICS
KEEP_DYNAMIC
UNICODE_CONVERSION
ROWSET_CURSOR
DYNAMIC_SCROLLABLE_CURSOR
FLEX_BLOCKING
PACKAGE_PATH
REOPT_ONCE
REOPT_ALWAYS
REOPT_NONE
SCROLL_ORIENTATION
DIV_SCALE
QUERY_INSTANCE
MULTIROW_INPUT
SQL_ATTRIBUTES
SQL_GET
SET
BIND_DEPLOY
DUP_QUERY_SEMANTICS
BINARY_XML_FORMAT
BIND_DEPLOY_FUNCTION
REMOTE_QUERY_OFFLOAD
ORDINARY_ARRAY_PARM
sub-code
A single-byte value that indicates how the error was detected in the network. If no additional information is available, this value is 0.
The local Db2 that is acting as the requester detected the error. The values that are provided for location-name and product-identifier identify the server in error.
The server detected the error. The values that are provided for location-name and product-identifier identify the location and level of the local Db2 server.
An intermediate server (hop site) detected the error. The values that are provided for location-name and product-identifier identify the server in error.

system_action.content: The statement cannot be processed. The SQLCA is formatted.

problem_determination.content: Use the reason-code value that was specified in the code to determine which function was not supported. Use the sub-code value to further identify the problem.

programmer_response.content: Notify the DBA for assistance in analyzing the SQL statement that prompted this SQLCODE.

msg_text.content: EXECUTION FAILED DUE TO A DISTRIBUTION PROTOCOL ERROR THAT CAUSED DEALLOCATION OF THE CONVERSATION: REASON reason-code (sub-code)

explanation.content: A DRDA protocol error has occurred that prevented the successful execution of the current SQL statement or command, as well as any subsequent SQL statements.

The 'reason-code' identifies the DDM code point which represents the DDM reply message received from the remote server in response to the attempt to execute the SQL statement. These represent internal errors detected at the remote server site or possibly, by the local Db2 functions.
The 'reason-code' value is the two-byte hexadecimal code point for the DDM reply message that represents the error and is one of the following:

children.content: X'1232' - AGNPRMRM
X'1254' - CMDCHKRM
X'220A' - DSCINVRM
X'220E' - DTAMCHRM
X'0010' - FDODSC
X'1218' - MGRDEPRM
X'1245' - PRCCNVRM
X'241A' - QRYDSC
X'2202' - QRYNOPRM
X'220F' - QRYPOPRM
X'2207' - RDBACCRM
X'2204' - RDBNACRM
X'124C' - SYNTAXRM

explanation.content: A two byte sub-code accompanies 'reason codes'. The sub-code, when nonzero, consists of two bytes such that the high-order byte indicates the site at which the error was detected. This is X'01' if the error was detected by the local Db2; It is X'02' if the error was detected by the remote server. The low-order byte is dependent upon the 'reason code' as follows:

children.content: Description Error Code (DSCERRCD) if reason code= X'220A ' (DSCINVRM).
Syntax Error Code (SYNERRCD) if reason code = X'124C ' (SYNTAXRM).
Conversational Protocol Error Code (PRCCVNCD) if reason code = X'1245' (PRCCNVRM).
Manager Dependency Error Code (DEPERRCD) if reason code = X' 1218' (MGRDEPRM).

explanation.content: Refer to Open Group Technical Standard, DRDA Version 3 Vol. 3: Distributed Data Management Architecture for a detailed discussion of the semantics of the DDM terms DSCERRCD, SYNERRCD, PRCCNVCD, and DEPERRCD.

system_action.content: The statement cannot be processed. The SQLCA is formatted and the conversation on which the error was detected is deallocated. Message DSNL031I or DSNL032I, which might contain additional diagnostic information, might be issued to the MVS console.

programmer_response.content: The connection to the server has been broken, and the server has, therefore, rolled back the unit of work. In this case, the only SQL statement that may be successfully executed is ROLLBACK. However, if the requester detects this error on a COMMIT, then it is unknown whether the unit of work was committed or rolled back at the server.

msg_text.content: EXECUTION FAILED DUE TO A DISTRIBUTION PROTOCOL ERROR THAT WILL AFFECT THE SUCCESSFUL EXECUTION OF SUBSEQUENT COMMANDS OR SQL STATEMENTS: MANAGER manager AT LEVEL level NOT SUPPORTED ERROR

explanation.content: A DRDA error occurred that prevented the successful execution of the current SQL statement or command and any subsequent SQL statements.

A manager-level conflict was detected during the processing of the DDM EXCSAT command. Refer to the Open Group Technical Standard, DRDA Version 3 Vol. 3: Distributed Data Management Architecture for a detailed description of EXCSAT processing and errors.

The manager value is the 2-byte hexadecimal code point of the DDM manager class identified as not supported in the EXCSATRD that reported the error. Refer to the DDM term MGRLVL in the Open Group Technical Standard, DRDA Version 3 Vol. 3: Distributed Data Management Architecture for the 2-byte hexadecimal values.

The level value is the 2-byte hexadecimal value of the manager level identified as not supported in the EXCSATRD that reported the error. Refer to the DDM term MGRLVL in the Open Group Technical Standard, DRDA Version 3 Vol. 3: Distributed Data Management Architecture for the 2-byte hexadecimal values.

programmer_response.content: Notify the system programmer for analysis of the condition that caused this SQLCODE.

msg_text.content: EXECUTION FAILED BECAUSE FUNCTION IS NOT SUPPORTED BY THE SERVER WHICH CAUSED TERMINATION OF THE CONNECTION: LOCATION location PRODUCT ID identifier REASON reason-code (sub-code)

explanation.content: The current SQL statement failed because the SQL statement was routed to a server that does not support the requested function. A new connection is required to allow the successful execution of further SQL statements.

children.content: location-name
The name of the server that could not support the required database protocols to perform the requested function.
identifier
A string in one of the following forms:
product-identifier
product-identifierclientapplcompat-valuepackage-applcompat-value
product-identifier
An alphanumeric string that identifies the product.

The format of product identifier values is pppvvrrm, where ppp is a 3-letter product code (such as DSN for Db2), vv is the version, rr is the release, and m is the modification level. For example, DSN12015 identifies Db2 12 after the activation of function level 500 or higher. The product code (ppp) is one of the following values: Modification (m) values have the following meanings:
for IBM Db2 Analytics Accelerator for z/OS
AQT
for DB2 Server for VSE & VM
ARI
for Db2 for z/OS
DSN
for IBM Data Server Driver for JDBC and SQLJ
JCC
for DB2 for i
QSQ
for Db2 for Linux, UNIX, and Windows
SQL
Function level 100 or 100*.
Function level 500 or higher.
clientapplcompat-value
The client application compatibility value that is provided by a client application: If the application does not provide a client application compatibility value, this value is an asterisk (*).
For applications that use Java drivers, clientapplcompat-value is the value of the clientApplcompat Connection or DataSource property for the connection to the Db2 for z/OS data server.
For applications that use other clients or drivers, such as the CLI driver, clientapplcompat-value is the value of the ClientApplCompat configuration keyword.
package-applcompat-value
The APPLCOMPAT bind option value for the package that was used to execute the first SQL statement in the application.
Related information:
Application compatibility for clients and drivers other than Java
Setting the Db2 for z/OS application compatibility for your JDBC and SQLJ applications
reason-code
A numeric value that identifies the function. Possible values are:For special instructions on actions to take when reason-code is 0600, see Database administrator response.
LONG_STMTS
LONG255_IDS
EXTENDED_DESCRIBE
EXTENDED_DIAGNOSTICS
KEEP_DYNAMIC
UNICODE_CONVERSION
ROWSET_CURSOR
DYNAMIC_SCROLLABLE_CURSOR
FLEX_BLOCKING
PACKAGE_PATH
REOPT_ONCE
REOPT_ALWAYS
REOPT_NONE
SCROLL_ORIENTATION
DIV_SCALE
QUERY_INSTANCE
MULTIROW_INPUT
SQL_ATTRIBUTES
SQL_GET
SET
BIND_DEPLOY
DUP_QUERY_SEMANTICS
BINARY_XML_FORMAT
BIND_DEPLOY_FUNCTION
CLIENTAPPLCOMPAT_INCONSISTENCY
sub-code
A single-byte value that indicates how the error was detected in the network. If no additional information is available, this value is 0.
The local Db2 that is acting as the requester detected the error. The values that are provided for location-name and product-identifier identify the server in error.
The server detected the error. The values that are provided for location-name and product-identifier identify the location and level of the local Db2 server.
An intermediate server (hop site) detected the error. The values that are provided for location-name and product-identifier identify the server in error.

system_action.content: The statement cannot be processed. The current unit of work is rolled back. The SQLCA is formatted.
If the reason-code is 0600, a companion DSNL076I message might also be issued to the Db2 server system console.

problem_determination.content: Use the reason-code value that was specified in the code to determine which function was not supported. Use the sub-code value to further identify the problem.

programmer_response.content: Contact the database administrator for assistance in analyzing the SQL statement that prompted this SQLCODE.

sql_state.content: If reason-code is 0600, use clientapplcompat-value and package-applcompat-value to determine the cause of the error and fix the problem:

children.content: If identifier is in the format product-identifierclientapplcompat-valuepackage-applcompat-value, clientapplcompat-value is greater than package-applcompat-value. clientapplcompat-value must be less than or equal to package-applcompat-value. Determine whether the application uses any capabilities for which the minimum function level is greater than package-applcompat-value. Then take one of the following actions:
If the application does not use any capabilities that require a higher application compatibility setting, change the client application compatibility setting to package-applcompat-value.

If the application uses capabilities that require clientapplcompat-value, use a version of the IBM data server driver or client for which the package application compatibility is greater than or equal to clientapplcompat-value.Query SYSIBM.SYSPACKAGES to find existing IBM data server driver or client packages at the right application compatibility level. If no packages exist, bind or rebind driver or client packages. For drivers only, you can use the DSNTIJLC job to bind copies of the driver packages, or the DSNTIJLR job to rebind the driver packages, at the correct application compatibility level.If you bind copies of the driver packages, you need to modify the configuration keyword or bind option that controls the current package set so that applications use the correct set of driver packages.See V12R1Mnnn application compatibility levels for data server clients and drivers for more information.

If identifier is in the format product-identifier*package-applcompat-value, a client application compatibility value was not set for the application. In addition, package-applcompat-value is greater than V12R1M500, and the client or driver is not at a level that supports the package APPLCOMPAT level package-applcompat-value. Take one of the following actions.
Upgrade the client or driver. Refer to  for information on required client driver levels.
V12R1Mnnn application compatibility levels for data server clients and drivers
Tip: It is recommended that after you upgrade the client or driver, set clientApplCompat for the application to a value that is less than or equal to package-applcompat-value.

If it is not yet possible to upgrade the client or driver, bind or rebind the client or driver packages with the APPLCOMPAT value set to V12R1M500 or lower.For drivers only, you can use the DSNTIJLC job to bind copies of the driver packages, or the DSNTIJLR job to rebind the driver packages, at the correct application compatibility level. If you bind copies of the driver packages, you need to modify the configuration keyword or bind option that controls the current package set so that applications use the correct set of driver packages.

msg_text.content: COMMIT REQUEST WAS UNSUCCESSFUL, A DISTRIBUTION PROTOCOL VIOLATION HAS BEEN DETECTED, THE CONVERSATION HAS BEEN DEALLOCATED. ORIGINAL SQLCODE=original-sqlcode AND ORIGINAL SQLSTATE=original-sqlstate

explanation.content: The application requested COMMIT operation was unsuccessful and the response from the remote server and the SQLCODE that was returned from the remote server are inconsistent. For example, the reply message from the remote server indicates that a COMMIT operation did not complete successfully but the SQLCODE returned from the remote server was greater than or equal to zero. The unit of work has been rolled back and the connection with the remote server has been deallocated.

system_action.content: An alert was generated. A DSNL031I message may have been written to the console. Refer to the description of this message for further information.
The SQLCODE returned by the remote server is replaced with -30030 and the SQLSTATE returned by the AS is replaced with '158013' and the connection with the remote server has been deallocated.
The SQLCODE and SQLSTATE values that were returned from the remote server are stored in the SQLERRM field in a string of the following format:

children.content: 'original-sqlcode 'FF'X original-sqlstate'

programmer_response.content: Notify the system programmer for assistance in analyzing the trace data that was generated.

msg_text.content: EXECUTION FAILED DUE TO UNAVAILABLE RESOURCES THAT WILL NOT AFFECT THE SUCCESSFUL EXECUTION OF SUBSEQUENT COMMANDS OR SQL STATEMENTS. REASON reason-code TYPE OF RESOURCE resource-type RESOURCE NAME resource-name PRODUCT ID product-identifier RDBNAME rdbname

explanation.content: The SQL statement or command requires a non-RDB resource that is currently unavailable.

children.content: reason-code
The Db2 reason code value that indicates the reason for the failure. For explanations of reason codes, see Db2 reason codes.
resource-type and resource-name
The type and name of the resource that the message identifies. For an explanation of resource-type and resource-name values, see Resource types.
product-identifier
An alphanumeric string that identifies the product.

The format of product identifier values is pppvvrrm, where ppp is a 3-letter product code (such as DSN for Db2), vv is the version, rr is the release, and m is the modification level. For example, DSN12015 identifies Db2 12 after the activation of function level 500 or higher. The product code (ppp) is one of the following values: Modification (m) values have the following meanings:
for IBM Db2 Analytics Accelerator for z/OS
AQT
for DB2 Server for VSE & VM
ARI
for Db2 for z/OS
DSN
for IBM Data Server Driver for JDBC and SQLJ
JCC
for DB2 for i
QSQ
for Db2 for Linux, UNIX, and Windows
SQL
Function level 100 or 100*.
Function level 500 or higher.
rdbname
A sixteen-byte string that identifies the RDBNAME.

system_action.content: The statement cannot be processed. The local Db2 is disconnected from the remote server.

programmer_response.content: Verify the identify of the resource that was not available. The reason the resource is unavailable is identified by the reason-code value.
Collect the following diagnostic items to help determine the cause of the unavailable resource:

children.content: Console output from the system identified by RDBNAME, and a listing of SYSLOG data set for the period of time spanning the failure.
Information described for the reason code received.

msg_text.content: EXECUTION FAILED DUE TO UNAVAILABLE RESOURCES THAT WILL AFFECT THE SUCCESSFUL EXECUTION OF SUBSEQUENT COMMANDS AND SQL STATEMENTS. REASON reason-code TYPE OF RESOURCE resource-type RESOURCE NAME resource-name PRODUCT ID product-identifier RDBNAME rdbname

explanation.content: The SQL statement or command requires a non-RDB resource that is currently unavailable.

children.content: reason-code
The Db2 reason code value that indicates the reason for the failure. For explanations of reason codes, see Db2 reason codes.
resource-type and resource-name
The type and name of the resource that the message identifies. For an explanation of resource-type and resource-name values, see Resource types.
product-identifier
An alphanumeric string that identifies the product.

The format of product identifier values is pppvvrrm, where ppp is a 3-letter product code (such as DSN for Db2), vv is the version, rr is the release, and m is the modification level. For example, DSN12015 identifies Db2 12 after the activation of function level 500 or higher. The product code (ppp) is one of the following values: Modification (m) values have the following meanings:
for IBM Db2 Analytics Accelerator for z/OS
AQT
for DB2 Server for VSE & VM
ARI
for Db2 for z/OS
DSN
for IBM Data Server Driver for JDBC and SQLJ
JCC
for DB2 for i
QSQ
for Db2 for Linux, UNIX, and Windows
SQL
Function level 100 or 100*.
Function level 500 or higher.
rdbname
A sixteen-byte string that identifies the RDBNAME.

system_action.content: The statement cannot be processed. The local Db2 is disconnected from the remote server.

programmer_response.content: Verify the identity of the resource that was not available. The reason the resource is unavailable is identified by the reason-code value:
Collect the following diagnostic items to help determine the cause of the unavailable resource.

children.content: Console output from the system identified by RDBNAME, and a listing of SYSLOG data set for the period of time spanning the failure.
Information described for the reason code received.

msg_text.content: EXECUTION FAILED BECAUSE THE DEFINITION OF OBJECT object-name OF TYPE object-type BEING ACCESSED AT server-name-1 DIFFERS FROM THE DEFINITION OF THE OBJECT AT server-name-2

explanation.content: The definition of the object, object-name, at server-name-1 does not match the definition of the object at server-name- 2. object-name must have identical definitions at both servers if either of the following SQL statement processing occurs, otherwise, the attempt to access object-name will fail:

children.content: An SQL statement is system directed at server-name-2 to run at server-name-1, and object-name is referenced or updated in the processing of that statement.

An SQL statement is processed at server-name-1 which is local to the application, and prior SQL statements of the application session had been directed to run at server-name-2 and had referenced or updated object-name.
object-name
The name of the object.
object-type
The type of object.
server-name-1
The name of the server that attempted to access the object. Up to 16 characters of the server name are displayed.
server-name-2
The name of the server from which the definition of the object was used to create an instance of the object on server-name-1. Up to 16 characters of the location name are displayed.

programmer_response.content: Correct the definition of object-name at either server-name-1 or server-name-2 so that the definitions at both servers are identical. Then rebuild and rerun the application.

msg_text.content: STATEMENT FAILED BECAUSE OBJECT OF TYPE object-type CANNOT BE ACCESSED USING DIFFERENT DISTRIBUTED PROTOCOLS ON A CONNECTION FROM server-name-1 TO server-name-2

explanation.content: SQL statements that reference object-type objects cannot be processed in the following cases:

children.content: The same connection between server-name-1 and server-name-2 uses both application-directed access and system-directed access.
Use of application-directed access and system-directed access are mixed in the application.
object-type
The type of object.
server-name-1
The name of the server that attempted to access the object. Up to 16 characters of the server name are displayed.
server-name-2
The name of the server from which the definition of the object was used to create an instance of the object on server-name-1. Up to 16 characters of the location name are displayed.

programmer_response.content: If the application is controlled by a plan bound at a Db2 for z/OS requester, and the application performs commits or rollbacks before any change in the distributed protocol used by the application, the plan should be rebound with the DISCONNECT bind option set to AUTOMATIC or CONDITIONAL. This will permit the requester to automatically terminate any remote server connection during commit or rollback processing.
